content: The "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009" aims to protect Federal lands along the US-Mexico border from unauthorized immigration, smuggling, and border enforcement activities while ensuring border security operations are carried out. In the "Border Security and Responsibility Act 2009," key terms defined include "Indian tribe," "Secretary," and "Secretary concerned," specifying their meanings in relation to the Act. The curr_chunk discusses the jurisdiction of different secretaries over specific lands. The curr_chunk focuses on the border protection strategy. The Secretary, along with other government officials, must develop a border protection strategy for the US international land borders by September 30, 2009, in consultation with tribal, State, and local officials. The strategy should include a comparative analysis of border security levels. The border protection strategy for US international land borders must include a comparative analysis of operational control levels achievable through various security measures such as pedestrian fencing and vehicle barriers near roads. The assessment shall include pedestrian fencing, vehicle barriers near roads, additional Border Patrol agents, natural barriers' effectiveness, and advanced technology like unmanned aerial vehicles. The assessment includes the use of advanced technology like unmanned aerial vehicles for border surveillance in difficult terrain and adverse environmental conditions. The curr_chunk discusses regional variations in border security methodologies, cooperation with Mexico and Canada, and assistance to intelligence agencies in detecting unauthorized activities. The curr_chunk focuses on providing assistance to intelligence, security, and law enforcement agencies in Mexico and Canada to detect and respond to unauthorized border crossings, as well as the removal of obstructive vegetation. It also includes a comprehensive analysis of the cost and impacts of security measures. The curr_chunk discusses the cost and impacts of security measures, including land acquisition, construction, maintenance, contractor, and management costs, as well as the effects on wildlife. The curr_chunk focuses on costs related to labor, materials, maintenance, contractors, management, and impacts on wildlife, habitats, and hydrology along the border. The curr_chunk discusses the impacts of hydrology on various lands along the border and the costs of mitigating these impacts, including wildlife habitats and water quality. The curr_chunk addresses the replacement or restoration of severed wildlife migration corridors with protected corridors of equivalent biological functionality, as determined by relevant authorities. The curr_chunk discusses the consultation with tribal, State, and local governments, as well as authorities from Mexico and Canada, regarding the impacts on culture, safety, and quality of life near the border. A comprehensive compilation of fiscal investments in acquiring or managing lands and waters near the United States border for conservation purposes, including protected wildlife migration corridors in National Park System units, National Forest System land, and other relevant areas. The legislation aims to protect wildlife migration corridors in federal lands under various agencies' jurisdictions, including the Department of the Interior, Department of Agriculture, Department of Defense, Department of Commerce, tribal lands, State and private lands, and lands within Mexico and Canada. Recommendations for strategic border security are also included. Recommendations for strategic border security management and required training by the Secretary are also included. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection training for Customs and Border Protection agents or other Federal personnel assigned to plan or oversee the construction or operation of border security tactical infrastructure or to patrol. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Secretary concerned, shall provide natural resource protection and cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure construction and operation. The Secretary, in cooperation with relevant tribal governments, shall provide cultural resource training for Customs and Border Protection agents and other Federal personnel involved in border security infrastructure construction and operation. The Secretary coordinates with relevant tribal governments to provide training focused on achieving border security objectives while minimizing adverse impacts on natural and cultural resources. SEC. 5. ACTIONS TO GAIN OPERATIONAL CONTROL OF THE INTERNATIONAL LAND BORDERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Amendment to improve operational control of the border. The Secretary of Homeland Security must gain operational control of the international land borders of the United States, following the border protection strategy. Priority should be given to using remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, unmanned aerial vehicles, and other low impact border enforcement techniques. The Secretary of Homeland Security should consult with various entities to minimize environmental and cultural impacts while implementing border enforcement techniques such as remote cameras, sensors, natural barriers, manpower, and unmanned aerial vehicles. The Secretary of Homeland Security should consult with relevant entities to minimize environmental and cultural impacts during border enforcement actions. This includes collaborating with the Secretary of the Interior, Agriculture, Defense, Commerce, States, local governments, tribal governments, and private property owners to mitigate the effects on the environment, culture, commerce, safety, and quality of life for nearby communities. The proposed subsection (a) outlines limitations and rules of construction, including not creating or negating rights of action, affecting eminent domain laws, or waiving other applicable laws. This section does not impose requirements contrary to subsection (a). This section does not impose requirements contrary to subsection (a). Additionally, the Secretary of Homeland Security is not required to install specific resources along the international border if deemed ineffective for achieving operational control. The Secretary of Homeland Security can choose not to use certain resources along the international border if they are not effective or if the costs and impacts outweigh the benefits. This decision must meet the requirements of section 102. The Secretary of Homeland Security must consider whether the costs and impacts of using certain resources along the international border outweigh the benefits before commencing any construction or awarding funds. The Secretary of Homeland Security must evaluate the costs and impacts of using resources along the international border before starting any construction or awarding funds. No roads, lighting, cameras, sensors, or tactical infrastructure can be implemented near the border until 90 days after the submission of the required border protection strategy to Congress. SEC. 6. BORDERLANDS MONITORING AND MITIGATION. The Secretary, in consultation with various agencies, will develop a monitoring and mitigation plan to address ecological impacts of border security infrastructure along US international land borders. The plan will include measures to mitigate environmental impacts. The mitigation plan for border security infrastructure along US international land borders must address ecological and environmental impacts, including preserving wildlife migration corridors and key habitats to ensure species viability. The mitigation plan must address preserving wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, maintaining hydrological functionality, and implementing measures to control invasive species. The mitigation plan must address preserving wildlife migration corridors, key habitats, maintaining hydrological functionality, incorporating adaptive management with long-term monitoring, necessary adjustments based on monitoring results, and protection of cultural and historical resources. The Secretary has the authority to carry out the mitigation plan on various types of lands. The Secretary has the authority to carry out the mitigation plan on Federal, State, local, tribal, or private lands near the international border of the United States, regardless of ownership. Activities must be done in consultation and with the concurrence of relevant parties. The Secretary of Homeland Security can transfer funds to other Federal agencies for expenditure under their programs, with activities carried out in consultation and with the concurrence of relevant parties. Transfer funds from the Department of Homeland Security to other Federal agencies for conservation activities on non-Federal lands and mitigation activities on Federal lands. The Secretary may accept and use donations for conservation and mitigation activities on Federal lands managed by agencies, exempting transferred funds from reprogramming requirements. The Secretary can accept donations for developing and implementing a mitigation plan without reprogramming requirements. Funds appropriated for border security can be used for this purpose. Authorization of Appropriations: Funds allocated to the Department of Homeland Security for border security can be utilized by the Secretary to create and execute the required mitigation plan.
